column1: Will domestic sales of passenger vehicles in India be higher in April-June 2020 compared with April-June 2019?
column6: ['Business', 'Economic Indicators']
The industry witnessed a substantial de-growth of 88% in May, with zero sales in April (SIAM)
Don't know enough about this.
April & May were way below 2019 level. June is also expected to be below 2019 level.
Highly unlikely to see higher sales due to supply chain issues, poor consumer sentiment, the higher cost of BS-IV standards and a general liquidity crunch in the lending sector.
Car sales had been declining. COVID will likely worsen sales.
Covid 19

While Covid will undoubtedly depress all economic activity, including auto sales, given how much 2019 sales for that period were lower compared to the previous year, there is a small chance that 2019 was impacted by other factors specific to that period.
It would take a crazy amount of car sales in June to be higher by year-to-year quarters.
Most of India is still in severe lockdown.
Over-all declining trend in passenger vehicle sales combined with impact of global pandemic.
Covid = no cars
COVID effect
Just a guess

It is extremely unlikely due to the pandemics impact both on social movement and the economy. With 287k cases and growing the chance of stricter measures being imposed continues increase which would limit the amount people travel and how much money they are able to spend on a vehicle.
Covid 19 and economic reality.
Coronavirus!
After not a single sale in April (-100% compared to 2019) they at least sold a few cars in May (-90%):

covid

- Already slowing industry - 0 sales in April
Coronavirus hit car sales hard in all affected countries.
Growth in April: -100% Makes me cry :-(
Most car manufacturers reported zero sales in April 2020. highly unlikely to recover
The pandemic has severely impacted all world economies.
reaffirming 0% based on the excellent comments by RRG below.
Indian passenger vehicle sales have been slowing over the past couple of years.
they sold zero cars in April. Yes, zero. Won’t be a quick rebound in this timeline

COVID-19 has already hit India auto sales hard. Major sellers reported no sales in April. Which alone is a massive reason why the other two months month be able to make for the loss in unit sales as compared to last year. As well, the COVID situation continues and the economy is struggling and increased car purchases don’t seem probable.
Covid-19 impact: 8-10% auto dealers face closure
Covid kills car sales and oil demand.
Sales this year we certainly be lower. There is talk of "zero sales" from both Toyota and Suzuki in April. [1] The March numbers were at about 51% of those in 2019 [2]
Unlikely due to uncertainty surrounding the covid outbreak
Lockdown, obviously.
Like the answers to so many things these days: CoVid.
Covid surely makes this impossible
Coronavirus guarantees that car sales will be lower this year than last year. This has been the trend in all countries.
Covid will kill off sales
Due to the current crisis it is not to be expected that car sales will increase.
Not a chance with the SARS COV 2 virus keeping them in lockdown.
Covid-19 has pulled back. https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/auto/auto-news/covid-19-to-pull-back-indias-passenger-vehicle-and-truck-market-by-a-decade/articleshow/75075507.cms?from=mdr
Covid, highly unlikely
Highly unlikely given current COVID-19 situation and lockdown slowing down the India economy.
Lockdown will need to be maintained in some capacity for this period
The impact of covid-19 means this is never going to happen
Oh my god ! https://www.autopunditz.com/news/indian-car-sales-figures-march-2020/
Country is currently in lock down due to pandemic with now known exit date. Would be highly unlikely that domestic sales would be more than last year
One gathers that the entire auto industry is shut down. Hard to sell something if you can't make it in the first place.
Lockdown on top of previous factors.
I've asked the moderator if I can go negative on this one. I have not heard back.
Adjusting to consensus
Impact of coronavirus on Indian economy puts a damper on growth.
COVID will significantly reduce demand and supply
India was already in recession before Covid-19, and auto sales are in a steep decline
seriously?
A dampened global economic outlook will curb consumer spending until summer. unlikely to see increased year on year spending.
CONVID19 is affecting economies worldwide
downward revision on account of market decline

Between a rising unemployment trend ( https://tradingeconomics.com/india/unemployment-rate ) and new emission standards scheduled for Q2 that will increase cost of purchase ( https://finance.yahoo.com/news/indias-car-sales-fall-january-112523614.html ), and concerns over COVID-19, I wouldn’t anticipate a YOY increase. Rating the chances at roughly 1 in 8.

Slowing growth (https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/economy/indicators/moodys-cuts-india-growth-projection-to-5-4-per-cent-for-2020/articleshow/74171366.cms) - note that this already factors in coronavirus so I won't double count that.
SIAM lists 2 causes for tepid sales - Vehicle Ownership cost and lower GDP growth.
There seem to be at least three intertwined issues determining the answer:
Coronavirus

Updating slightly downward. Car sales have fallen precipitously in China as a result of the coronavirus outbreak, and a similar picture would emerge in India if it were to start spreading rapidly. Coronavirus cases outside mainland China are currently rising exponentially, and while India is monitoring thousands of people—and has successfully overseen the recovery of three people—its underfunded healthcare system combined with its population density and high internal migration could mean that the country’s economy will be hit hard if an epidemic arises.
Trade slowing sharply because of world markets and corona.
Small update based upon data I hadn’t seen.
Because sales have increased every year for the past decade and the economy is doing well.

Basically with a lot of the world still in recession. The growing Indian middle class have bought the cars and are quiet happy to sit back and wait for the world to get it self sorted out before buying another new car. They say the 21st century is the time for Asia to bloom, but even the likes of China, India etc are now seeing their economy’s slow down etc
Misread question in my last submission

Indian passenger car sales has been falling Year in year mostly because of the lingering effects of demonetisation and now the disruption of the manufacturing supply chain due to the Chinese coronavirus
World economic slowdown as trade shrinks due to virus impacts and uncertainties in immigration policy and conflicts on northers border intensify.
It is the economy and locally produced cars
manufacturers will lower car prices to encourage purchase
Reduced car sales will encourage lowering of prices to encourage buyers increasing take up of new cars

Economic Times: During January in the passenger vehicles segment, market leader Maruti Suzuki India witnessed 0.29 per cent increase in sales at 1,39,844 units. Rival Hyundai Motor India saw its sales decline by 8.3 per cent at 42,002 units, while Mahindra & Mahindra saw a decline of 17.05 per cent at 19,794 units. Given coronavirus and world economy slowdown I am lowerin more.
Reversion to the mean
Economy heating up
With coronavirus hitting economies worldwide I am going to lower.

India faced a slump in its GDP and household incomes during the last year. With the Streamlining of GST, and expected upturn in the economy, its expected teh consumer confidence will rise, hence leading to investing in cars/bikes etc.
Editing initial forecast. Sales keep falling

From the Economist re latest budget: “In most big economies the government’s budget plans seldom drive large movements in the stockmarket. Except in India. Bosses and investors parse the documents for clues about which industries or firms gained favour and which fell out of it. Markets react accordingly. In February 2008 the Mumbai bourse’s main index fell by 12% in five days after India’s then-rulers were perceived to have responded inadequately to the global financial crisis. This year’s budget came on February 1st, a Saturday. Stockmarkets held a special weekend session. Bosses and investors were glued to tv screens as the finance minister, Nirmala Sitharaman, recited the provisions—until, after a record two hours and 41 minutes, she was too exhausted to go on.
The budget presented in february, 2020 has been well received. The latest Reserve Bank of India credit policy is also favorable.
This is the pause between elections. So no free money.
No corrective measures have been reported. Without corrective structural measures, it is difficult to conceive how the economy encourages consumers to go out and spend more on big ticket items.

Will domestic sales of passenger vehicles in India be higher in April-June 2020 compared with April-June 2019? I am following the logic of @Hammer-Time on this thread. The economy continues to slow and big ticket items suffer the most. Not sure if the coronavirus will be a factor, but its clearly not an economic positive.
There is an uprising against the intellectual class, Modi is whipping up Hindu nationalism and some coronavirus cases are spilling over. Instability will hurt economic activity. Lowering.
The economic problem
Lowering. World economy taking a hit with coronovirus.
Much of the downturn is from protectionist tariffs which will continue to slow growth

View from December 2019 (Foreign Policy): "The economy is stalling. Data released last week shows that India’s economy expanded by just 4.5 % between July and September, its sixth consecutive quarter of slowing growth. The new figures represent a stunning decline: The country’s GDP was growing by more than 9% at the start of 2016, and by 8.1% as recently as early 2018. The unemployment rate stood at around 7.5% in November, with a record-low 42% labor participation rate. As a result, consumer demand has weakened, leading to a perpetual cycle of slowing manufacturing, production, investment, and job creation.
government incentives (7% sales tax rebate tied to car-purchase loan) not enough relative to price of EVs as most EV' loans to buy won't reach max incentive
Unless there is a economic slowdown, India's growing middle class will want to catch up to the middle class of China, as a matter of national pride.

Inside view: passenger vehicle sales in India have continued to drop. The article expects sales from April to be flat. https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/auto/auto-news/passenger-vehicle-sales-see-sharpest-drop-in-20-years-in-2019/articleshow/73186469.cms Price hikes are also likely to have an impact. https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/auto/cars-uvs/buying-a-bs6-car-next-year-get-ready-to-shell-out-more/articleshow/72880187.cms?from=mdr
Did more research. Definitely a collapse of car market last year. The Coronavirus might decrease it for now. Hard to tell if collapse was temporary. Lowering for now.
?pandemic
India is moving up

11 of 12 months had negative growth in '19 compared to '18. The Apr-Jun '19 quarter had a negative growth of -18.5% compared to the same quarter in '18. While regression to the mean is expected, current projections have sale of passenger cars are expected to be flat in the fiscal year starting April 2020 due to continuing weak demand and the onset of tighter emission norms that will drive up car prices. Local sales continued to fall 1.2% in December '19 compared to December 18'. Given this, starting my initial forecast with greater odds that passenger sales will be lower in 2020, but will update accordingly after seeing early 2020 numbers.

GDP growth while disappointing is still projected to be 5.8%, only a small fraction of people have cars, interest rate declines and more anticipated will be supportive of those that finance. Sales were way down in April June 2019 mean reversion could do it alone.
India economy expected to grow by 5.8%.

Outside view: Regression to the mean and the consistent upwards trend for the previous years suggest yes. => ~80% Inside view: Car prices are likely going to increase (https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/industry/auto/cars-uvs/buying-a-bs6-car-next-year-get-ready-to-shell-out-more/articleshow/72880187.cms?from=mdr). => ~50%
@Hammer-Time's India Today article.
India's growth has been slowing, there's probably some momentum effect as well.

New emissions protocol coming in April along with a ~10% price increase - in a market very sensitive to price increases. Agree with India Today - mostly flat sales overall with some buying prior to this (to avoid increase). So I’m on the low end..
Regression to the mean. 2018 year was all time high sale of passenger vehicles. 2019, the trend was a sharp down turn.
